April 2022 County of Marin EMS ALS PR 14
KING AIRWAY PROCEDURE
Indications
• When ventilation cannot be adequately maintained by BLS techniques, intubation is anticipated
to be difficult, or intubation is unsuccessful after one attempt
Equipment
Pre-procedure
• King Airway
• Open airway and pre-oxygenate with BVM for 1-3
• Syringe
min with 100% O2. Avoid hyperventilation in cardiac
• Water soluble lubricant
arrest
• Portable suction device
• Test cuff according to manufacturer’s instructions
• Capnometry/capnography or
• Apply water soluble lubricant to distal end of the tube
Colorimetric device
• Position the head into the “sniffing” position or
• Stethoscope
neutral position if trauma is suspected
• Remove dentures before placing tube to prevent
laceration of the cuffs King Tube Sizing
Size Patient Color Inflation
Criteria Volume
Procedure 3 4-5ft Yellow 45-60ml
• Without exerting excessive force, advance tube until
4 5-6ft Red 60-80ml
base of connector is aligned with teeth or gums
5 >6ft Purple 70-90ml
• Inflate cuffs based on size of tube
• Attach bag-valve to King Airway
• If necessary, withdraw airway until ventilation is easy
and free flowing the
• Verify placement using all of the following
• Rise and fall of chest
• Bilateral breath sounds
• Capnometry/capnography or colorimetric device
• Secure the tube with tape or commercial tube holder,
noting depth marking on tube
Critical Information
• Contraindications:
• Responsive patient with an
intact gag reflex
SPECIAL CONSIDERATIONS
• Patient with known
• If there is any doubt about the proper placement
esophageal disease
of the King Airway, deflate the cuffs and remove
• Patients who have ingested
device; ventilate the patient with BVM for 30
caustic substances
seconds and repeat sequence of steps
• Tracheal stoma
• If unsuccessful on second attempt, resume BLS
• Patient fits on length based
airway management
resuscitation tape
